title: Force of Gravity, Weight and Friction
author: S J Jabbar (Modernized)
description: Introduction to gravitational force, weight, and frictional forces

sections.text:
This chapter introduces the fundamental concepts of gravitational force,
weight, and friction. These are essential building blocks for understanding
mechanics and motion.

GRAVITY:

Gravity is a force that attracts all objects with mass toward each other.
On Earth, this force pulls objects toward the center of the planet.

The acceleration due to gravity on Earth is approximately 9.8 m/s^2.
What is the approximate acceleration due to gravity on Earth in m/s^2?

Correct! The acceleration due to gravity is approximately 9.8 m/s^2.
This means that in the absence of air resistance, all objects near
Earth's surface accelerate downward at this rate.

WEIGHT:

Weight is the force exerted on an object due to gravity.
It is calculated as: Weight = mass x gravitational acceleration

Weight is measured in Newtons (N), where 1 N = 1 kg*m/s^2

If an object has a mass of 10 kg, what is its weight on Earth?
(Use g = 10 m/s^2 for simplicity, answer in Newtons)

Excellent! Weight = mass x g = 10 kg x 10 m/s^2 = 100 N.
Remember that weight is a force, so it's measured in Newtons.

FRICTION:

Friction is a force that opposes motion between two surfaces in contact.
There are two main types:
  1. Static friction - prevents motion from starting
  2. Kinetic friction - opposes motion that is already occurring

Friction depends on the nature of the surfaces and the normal force.
Does friction oppose or assist motion?

That's right! Friction opposes motion. However, friction is not always
unwanted - it's what allows us to walk, and vehicles to grip the road!
